citation.article-title: Deinobacterium chartae gen. nov., sp. nov., an extremely radiation-resistant, biofilm-forming bacterium isolated from a Finnish paper mill
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Deinobacterium chartae sp. nov.
Deinobacterium chartae (char′tae. L. gen. fem. n. chartae of/from paper).
Exhibits the following properties in addition to those given in the genus description.
Plate-grown cells are 0.8–1.3 μm in width and 1.4–2.5 μm in length, may grow to filaments up to 40 μm in rich liquid medium.
Stains Gram-negatively, but has features of Gram-positive cells.
Catalase and oxidase-positive, urease-negative.
Forms colonies with pale pink pigment on R2A agar.
Growth occurs at 12 to 50 °C (optimum 37 to 45 °C) and between pH 6 and 10.3.
Growth is inhibited in the presence of >3 % (w/v) NaCl.
Anaerobic growth does not occur on TSA.
Produces acid from glucose, fructose and maltose.

The fatty acid composition is listed in Table 1.
MK-8 is the only respiratory quinone.

The lipid profile consists of three unknown aminophospholipids, of which one is the predominant lipid, one unknown phospholipid, four unknown glycolipids, two unknown aminolipids and one unknown polar lipid.
Peptidoglycan structure is A3β l-Orn–Gly–Gly and the DNA G+C content of the type strain is 66.8 mol%.
May be grown on R2A or TSA at 45 °C in ambient air.
The type strain, K4.1T (=DSM 21458T =HAMBI 2721T), was isolated from a biofilm collected from a Finnish paper mill.
